There's a ton of nostalgia you get every time you watch this movie - whether it is the subplots of the characters, the hilarious scenes executed by the gremlins, or the triumphs of victory by your favorite characters throughout the film in what seems like impossible odds. This is an all time classic and my favorite film of all time. I easily score this a 10/10.

title: Gremlins
content: Joe Dante (Piranha, The Howling) directed this fun mix of horror and humor. It's kinda like what I would picture a live action version of Looney Tunes. Looney Tunes animator Chuck Jones even has a cameo at Dorey's Tavern.Billy Peltzer (Zach Galligan) receives a strange, but cute new pet for Christmas. His new pet "Gizmo" comes with a set of special care instructions. He hates bright light. Keep him out of sunlight it will kill him. Don't get him wet. Never feed him after midnight.Of course Gizmo accidentally gets wet, resulting in six new creatures similar to Gizmo. The lead of the new pack has a mohawk, so they call him Stripe. Stripe and his group are different from Gizmo. They're more mischievous.The rule about being feed after midnight also gets broken. This results in the new creatures going into cocoons and emerging in a new form. One that more mischievous. The new creatures, Gremlins get out and wreck havoc all over Kingston Falls. It's up to Billy and his crush Kate (Phoebe Cates), along with Gizmo to try and stop Stripe and the other Gremlins.The supporting cast includes: Hoyt Axton, Judge Reinhold (Fast Times at Ridgemont High, Beverly Hills Cop), Dick Miller (The Howling, The Terminator), and Jackie Joseph (Little Shop of Horrors).Did you know that Gizmo was originally supposed to turn into a Gremlin? This is why he is carried around in a backpack during the second half of film.

title: Never Get Him Wet
content: This movie really struck a nerve with my son. He watched it numerous times and did impressions of little Gizmo for years. This is really a sendoff of all kinds of horror movies, but with a real sense of humor. The little guy is so darned cute. He is cuddly and actually kind of pretty. Of course, we know from the beginning that things will go haywire. What is neat about this film is that what happens is so darned much fun. Gizmo's offspring are pure evil. They relish every kind of anti-social behavior. They are like a bunch of drunk teenagers who have lost any sense of order, willing to provide hurt to anyone who gets in their way. They have the appearance of bats or mosquitoes or some sort of hybrid. They are Gizmo gone bad. There are lot of pretty good character actors in this film who find themselves bewildered by what happens. I was surprised to see a country singer, Hoyt Axton, playing the father. I just remember a song called "Bony Fingers." This works delightfully, but not until incredible mayhem is launched.

title: One of the most original, fun, imaginary, chaotic but most of all charming films ever.
content: From the opening sequence to the end credits, Gremlins has a certain charm to it. Perhaps it was the directing style of Joe Dante, or the screenplay by Chris Columbus. Whichever, it is a fun, entertaining and imaginative film.Gizmo (voiced by a young Howie Mandel) is a true creature effect, as are the Gremlins. This is one film that would have lost its charm if it were made today. The fact that we barely ever see Gizmo's feet when he runs, or the Gremlins lower bodies is wonderful. It is part of the charm that this film carries. I wouldn't want to see Gizmo looking like Yoda from the newest Star Wars films, cheap and unrealistic. It's great to have little creature creations, with real, fake fur (I know that sounds dumb but think about it).The cast is not extra ordinary, which makes it also feel so fun to watch, but nevertheless, the cast is still great, though the character of Billy wasn't the best they could have chosen, but like I said, that's part of the fun of it all.Gremlins has to be one of the most chaotic, entertaining, mesmerizing, adventurous, revolutionary, charming, fun-filled films of the past twenty years. 4/4 stars-John

title: Really Gremful
content:
Gremlin is what horror, action movies should be like.No dirty CGI
Noo bad acting
NoOo political agenda
Noooo annoying charactersThe movie is about Gremlins causing havoc all over the city.Verdict: Gremful

title: Amazing and fun...but it loses a point for the Phoebe Cates speech about Christmas!
content: "Gremlins" has one big thing going for it and it helped the movie to be the fourth largest box office draw of the year...it was FUN. Too many times, movies can depress you or make you uncomfortable...but sometimes it just is nice to have some fun and see something mindless (in a good way).Billy's father brings him a most unusual present...a creature called a Mogwai. Billy names it Gizmo and the creature is almost too cute. Unfortunately, if it gets wet or eats after midnight...very bad things happen. Those bad things make up about 75% of the movie.The film is cute but has an amazing sense of humor. I loved the "Seven Dwarves" scene and there were many other wonderful scenes throughout the movie. The only bad thing, and this prevents it from receiving a 10, is the god-awful speech by Phoebe Cates' character when she talks about Christmas and dead Santa. How did this make it into the movie?! And, it's so bad I can see how many audience members laughed at this supposedly poignant moment. Otherwise, a perfect film if you want to have fun and just enjoy yourself.

title: Memorable 80's product still packs a mean punch.
content: I would consider this my favourite Christmas movie of all time. And if your tastes tend towards the dark, twisted, and subversive, and you enjoy a healthy amount of humour with your horror, I'm sure you consider this essential Christmas viewing as well.It was the brainchild of Chris Columbus, whose screenplay caught the attention of Steven Spielberg who then suggested Joe Dante as director. Spielberg had enjoyed both Dantes' "Jaws" send-up "Piranha", as well as "The Howling", and the two had also directed segments of the previous years' notorious "Twilight Zone: The Movie". The story centres around bank teller and aspiring artist Billy Peltzer (Zach Galligan), whose travelling salesman / inventor father Rand (singer / songwriter / actor Hoyt Axton) picked up an unusual Christmas present for Billy during a visit to Chinatown: a cute little fuzzy animal identified as a Mogwai, whom Rand christens Gizmo. Gizmo comes with a set of insane rules, which of course must be followed and which, naturally, are meant to be broken soon enough: he must not be exposed to bright light, *especially* sunlight, he must not come into contact with water, and he must not eat after midnight. Rule # 2 is broken, and Gizmo spawns a quintet of new Mogwai that prove to be absolutely incorrigible. When rule # 3 is broken (unknowingly), the new Mogwai become Gremlins (the name coming from WWII, when any machinery experiencing problems would be said to have 'gremlins' in it), little reptilian monsters that proceed to tear an idyllic small town to pieces.This continues to hold up on repeat viewings. Even if there are firmly dated aspects to the presentation at times (Mega madness!), it's still as fun as it ever was, with an endearing human cast in addition to the diminutive "stars". Galligan and sexy Phoebe Cates are an appealing lead couple, Axton and Frances Lee McCain are a delight as the parents, Polly Holliday is just a riot as the crabby, greedy local busybody Mrs. Deagle (a perfect '80s stand in for Mr. Potter from "It's a Wonderful Life"), and Judge Reinhold a hoot as smarmy and ambitious bank vice-president Gerald. Superb supporting players include the *always* welcome Dick Miller as Mr. Futterman (who's reunited with his co-star from "The Little Shop of Horrors", Jackie Joseph), Scott Brady, Edward Andrews, Glynn Turman, Keye Luke, Corey Feldman, Jonathan Banks, Harry Carey, Jr., Belinda Balaski, and The Real Don Steele, the real life D.J. who will be familiar to fans of New World productions from the '70s. Appearing uncredited are veterans Kenneth Tobey and William Schallert. Spielberg and composer Jerry Goldsmith make fleeting appearances which the viewer will want to watch for. The voice artists are all fun, including Howie Mandel as Gizmo, and ultra ubiquitous Frank Welker as Stripe; "Police Academy" series sound effects guy Michael Winslow is also among this bunch.Excellent and highly enjoyable effects by Chris Walas and his team, Goldsmiths' irresistible score including that "Gremlin Rag" main theme, and numerous in-jokes and visual gags add to the fun. The title characters are never less than entertaining - sometimes frightening, sometimes extremely funny - and one can't help but like these guys - after all, they can't be *all* bad when they like "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" so much. They kind of have the personalities of children, albeit children whose pranks have a decidedly sadistic nature. And when they raise Hell in a tavern, they're just as obnoxious and destructive as any human drunks. The scene with McCain dispatching three of the monsters in her kitchen justifiably gave the movie its reputation. It's show stopping stuff, although the business with the microwave (not to mention Cates' priceless story of why she dislikes the Christmas season) did rub a fair amount of people the wrong way. And when all is said and done with this movie, there is a very blatant yet effective message about learning to be responsible.Followed by a sequel six years later, "Gremlins" would prove to be so successful - and merchandise friendly, no doubt - that it would get a theatrical re-release, and lead to a number of other imitative comedy / horror movies about little monsters - "Critters", "Troll", "Ghoulies", "Hobgoblins", and their sequels - but leads the pack by far.Nine out of 10.

title: My favorite Christmas movie of all time.
content: Usually, when we think of Christmas movies, we think of flicks like "It's a Wonderful Life". Well, here's a new kind: "Gremlins". This has got to be one of the coolest movies ever made. Joe Dante - always a director with some neat ideas - couldn't have pulled it off better.It all begins when inventor Rand Peltzer (Hoyt Axton) buys a furry little creature called "mogwai" from a Chinese salesman (Keye Luke). There are three rules about mogwai: 1) Never expose him to bright light (the sun could kill him). 2) Never expose him to water (certainly don't give him a bath). 3) The most important rule of all is never, ever, EVER, under any circumstances, feed him after midnight. So, Rand gives mogwai to his son Billy (Zach Galligan). But, as you might have guessed, the rules get broken, and before long, the little town of Kingston Falls is overrun by mean, green gremlins.Everything that you love about movies, you're likely to find in "Gremlins". Whether it's the inside jokes (a cinema is showing "A Boy's Life" and "Watch the Skies", the working titles for "E.T." and "Close Encounters of the Third Kind", respectively), the indictment of vicious landlady Ruby Deagle (Polly Holliday), Lynn Peltzer's (Frances Lee McCain) battles with the gremlins, or the overall jab at a "wholesome American small town", this is a top-notch thriller/comedy. I'm sure that Phoebe Cates is proud to have gotten an early role in this (she plays Billy's girlfriend Kate Beringer). And since this is a Joe Dante movie, B-movie actor Dick Miller of course gets a role: he plays sour neighbor Murray Futterman.Maybe this is just me, but I've noticed some similarities between "Gremlins" and "Ghostbusters". The obvious one is that they're both about things that nobody wants around town, but there's more. They're both plural nouns beginning with "G". "Gremlins" has 8 letters, "Ghostbusters" has 12; 8 and 12 are both divisible by 4. Both movies were released on 8 June 1984 (a year ending with 4, a day divisible by 4).Oh well, maybe I'm the only one who would even notice that. The point is that this is one great movie, and everyone should see it. 10/10.

title: Never Gets Old!
content: Gremlins (1984, Dir. Joe Dante)When Billy Peltzer is given a small creature called a Mogwai by his father, he is unaware of the carnage he is about to encounter. There is a huge responsibility in looking after Gizmo as there are certain rules which must be followed. The Mogwai must be kept away from bright light, never made wet and never, ever be fed after midnight. When an accident occurs involving Gizmo and water, the next evolution stage of the Mogwai appears, and it isn't nice at all.Now, who hasn't heard of gremlins, yet alone seen 'gremlins'? 'Gremlins' is one of those films, that although it's not perfect, never gets old. It's has both is scary moments and also it's comedy moments, whilst not going over the top. The gremlins still look amazingly real, and although there are a few dodgy shots compared to todays standards, the actual gremlins are beautifully made and operated. Although, 'Gremlins' isn't really a family film, it is a film that the whole family can enjoy. It the type of film that can even be viewed during the Christmas holiday. It's just a great big bunch of Spielberg fun and can not be missed!"The old bat never looked better." - Mr. Jones (Chuck Jones)

title: A fun little horror movie!
content: Young banker Billy Peltzer (Zach Galligan) is given a pet creature by his father, inventor Randall Peltzer (Hoyt Axton), for Christmas. However, after inadvertently breaking the rules concerning the creature of no light, no water and no food after midnight, the creature multiplies into mischievous, threatening and dangerous little monsters.This movie has a good mixture of comedic and scary moments, from the creatures attacking the people and the small town to Randall's funny, malfunctioning inventions. The acting was pretty good and seem genuine - not overly done or overzealous - just right. The plot was fast-paced and to-the-point and the story was just full of surprising moments; you'll never know where one of those Gremlins will jump out at you. And, Jerry Goldsmith's music score had just the right touch for this movie - it's catchy, creepy, jumpy and crafty-sounding - perfect for the gremlins.I wished the story showed more aftermath and some sort of an emergency response after the gremlins started attacking, rather than resorting to the tactics of the two useless sheriffs. Overall, though, this is a fun little horror movie and that is great laugh-out-loud and creepy entertainment.Grade A-

title: Classic
content: Christmas is in the air and Billy (Zach Galligan) gets an early gift from his father. He finds a tiny, cuddly Mogwai, a creature that is mysterious yet cute, which he names Gizmo (voiced by Howie Mandel) and the two bond. Billy is told a certain set of rules the Mogwai must follow: don't expose them to light, don't let them get wet, and above all else, don't feed them after midnight. When Billy inadvertently breaks one of the rules, the Mogwai transform into sinister creatures that multiply and wreak havoc across the quiet town. With the help of Kate (Phoebe Cates), Billy and Gizmo must control the problem before the Gremlins take over.On a massive scale, Joe Dante was given the task of bringing tiny, animatronic creatures to life, and he succeeds on a massive level. The creation of these creatures, from design to execution, lands this film as one of the most memorable creatures in cinema history. Placing this film in a tight-knit community that has Christmas plastered all over it, is the perfect place to set hundreds of creatures.All of the acting in this film lets the audience become one of the townspeople. Everyone is inviting, and this helps the film succeed by letting the viewer attach themselves to the characters. Even Gizmo and the evil gremlin Spike (voiced by Frank Welker) have a story arc that could have carried this film. To me, being invested in the characters leaves a bigger impression than the plot of a story. This is a major reason the film has lasted generations.Gremlins is billed as a family film, which it is at heart and partially in execution. This film was created before the PG-13 rating, so it is not for children under a certain age. This is, however, a perfect gateway horror film for young audiences to test the waters. It says a lot about a film when the biggest problem is a rating system that hasn't been put in place yet.This is, and forever will be, a Christmas and horror classic. I have fond memories of the Gremlins franchise and it had a major impact on the way I watch movies and the types of movies that have molded me. I, and others, look forward to passing this film down for generations, showing them how practical effects stand the test of time and letting them think that glitch in the TV could be a little gremlin toying with the controls.

title: I am not a Movie ! I am a Cartoon !! (screen) (vhs) (DVD)
content: The opposite is more frequent: the cartoons would like to be movies, either with a realistic art ("Final Fantasy"),or with real live actors ("Who framed Roger Rabbit ?" or "Looney Tunes Back in Action" from the same director).Here you got first a really lively setting: a small American town in the 80's. Then, it turns into an horror movie (the symbolic fight of the desperate housewife in her kitchen), and when it could have been a bloody nightmare, the monsters suffer from "gremlins madness" and it becomes a hilarious, funny horror movie: I think that with "Ghostbusters" (seen both in theaters for Christmas 84 at 10 years old), it was the first ones of this kind.In addition to the nostalgia, the enjoyment comes from a lot of merit (the name of Spielberg as producer may not be fortuitous): - Christmas time. It gives a good contrast to the horrorJerry Goldsmith music: two great theme: the romantic mogwai song & the frenzy gremlins themeJoe Dante as a director: he has the sense to make fun as well as to frightenA great collection of characters greatly interpreted: from the failed inventor and father, the nationalist neighbor, to an horrible "Mrs. Deagle" and so on Well, all of them bring theirs personal stories to the storyThe metaphoric script: the gentle Gizmo is "the nature gift" (as said from the old Chinese) and the gremlins are what happens when responsibility fails. Spiderman or Plato should agree with this. And as it is funny, every one accept to see the bad sides of human nature.Finally, the special effects are top: without any digital help, Gizmo & his pals seem truly alive.A must seen movie !

title: Good Movie!
content: I liked Gremlins. I was not expecting much because I thought that this film was one of those ridiculous 80's horror films. But, when I saw the names of Steven Spielberg and Joe Dante, I decided to give this movie a try. I was pleased at the result.This film starts with an inventor buying an unusual gift for his son, a Mogwai. They are cute creatures, but there are three important rules they must follow. When all these rules are broken, the Mogwai transforms into nastier creatures. They decide to wreak some havoc.The acting is good. I liked Zach Galligan, Pheobe Cates, Corey Feldman, and Judge Reinhold. They set the tone of the film.The special effects are great. I liked the creatures and in today movies, they would still look real.The score by Jerry Goldsmith is another beauty of a score.There is a great mixture of comedy and horror. I was either laughing or cowering. This is not the best film ever, but it's still pretty good. I rate this film 8/10.

title: Great Film
content: "What superior popular moviemaking is all about" (Richard Corliss, Time).Gremlins is a great film. Directed and designed beautifully this film utilizes practical effects, horror and comedy to create a classic Christmas film for the whole family. The production design, props, and special effects are all done so well. I love the use of practical effects and I wish movies today used them more, we know if this was made today the Gremlins would have been CGI and the fact that they are practical makes it 10x better. The story is pretty simple and the film is really good at showing as opposed to telling. With its use of the rules and showing us what happens when the Mogwai get wet or eat after midnight.Overall, Gremlins is a great film. It's well made and well executed. The story isn't complex, it is simple and easy to follow and the practical effects are amazing. I also really liked the soundtrack, there are a few really good songs in there. I think Gremlins is a good time for the whole family, doesn't require much attention, is easy to enjoy, and is a very well made and well directed film. I recommend everyone watches Gremlins in their lifetime.

title: 35 years later still a classic
content: When this movie came out, it competed against not only Ghostbusters, but Top Secret, a box office farce that was more of a failure during the second weekend of June 1984, a few months before the 1984 Summer Olympics brought box office down a bit in the states. It was also the first movie to feature the return of the WB Shield, which would remain in that form for 14 years until a CGI version debuted to celebrate Warner Bros' 75th anniversary and has remained unchanged ever since. As for the movie, it was this movie, as well as temple of doom, that forced the MPAA to create a new rating: PG-13, which nowadays kids can go see anyways unlike the R rating. The first movie to be released with the rating was Red Dawn, which became a cult hit and spawned a bad remake, but the first movie made was The Flamingo Kid, which failed at the box office. six years later, gremlins would make a comeback in Gremlins 2: The New Batch, which didn't do well at first but has become a cult classic on its own and makes fun of pop culture.

title: A fun film
content: Gremlins is one of the all time best fun family movies ever made. Without thinking, it must have been a fun film to make, let alone watch. The story line, characters, and even the setting are so enjoyable that a plot isn't even needed. Everything about the movie is already fun.

title: Clever, creepy, Christmasy, and loads of fun! Gremlins should be a part of everyone's Christmas traditions!
content: Gremlins should be at the top of everyone's favorite Christmas movie list. It's full of the 80s teenage adventure cheesiness, cute cuddly creatures, and creepy monsters. Gremlins radiates the same classic spirit and tone as other films of the time, like The Goonies or E. T., but Gremlins adds a little horror flavor. Admittedly, the film isn't particularly scary as it seeks to poke fun at more serious alien critter movies of the time. Still, its creepy atmosphere and twisted little monsters, mixed with the holiday cheer and quaintness of the quiet small town of Kingston Falls, set it apart from other 80s creature features. For many, sitting around the Christmas tree, sipping hot chocolate, and watching Gremlins is a yearly tradition. It might be a little dated, but Gremlins is a fun, adventurous film unlike any other Christmas movie.

title: Parents should read more about movies before taking their kids.
content: This is the movie that caused PG-13, because all the parents didn't pay attention to the reviews or the trailers and just saw a cutesy movie. They took their kids to it to find it's a monster movie where people drop like flies. So, they threw a **** storm to end all **** storms and PG-13 was born. Of course this didn't happened in Japan when Gremlins was just another movie. This is the kind of "violence" they should to five year old on Sailor Moon, they don't hide death from children, it's stupid. We're "protecting" our children to death in this country and I say it's enough. Time we were more like Japan and I would start by disbanding the PTA, considering it's not improving our schools any, like it was designed to do, instead they complain about movies and TV. Dispand the PTA today! Anyway, the movie was good but I prefer Polly Holiday as the nice person, not the evil Banker lady. I give GREMLINS...9 STARS!

title: Another one of the 80's finest
content: Throughout the 80's cinema goers experienced some incredible movies and were treated to some very special moments and Gremlins firmly cements itself into the top draw of the era.While Gremlins is a "Very" black comedy it still appeals to most people. Whether it's the scary side, or the cute side (provided by Gizmo) the film delights and scares people still to this day.After viewing both of the films again very recently with my girlfriend, who has never seen either before, it was great to see the reaction of a new viewer watching 25 years after its release.Very well directed, shame about some of the acting and some of the music pieces are haunting.Now what makes it so special? Well ...to be honest i don't know, it just has a magic factor to it that holds you throughout and keeps you wanting to revisit time after time. Having both Gremlins and Gremlins 2 in your DVD/Blu-ray collection is a must, if not i urge you to pick them up! Especially if you have never seen them! Now all i have to decide is which film is better 1 ...or 2?

title: Gremlins
content: Appealing comedy/horror about a cute, fuzzy animal that multiplies into into an army of mischievous and repulsive creatures. All hell breaks loose! The film is entertaining for all ages. Followed by a sequel.

title: There are just three rules...
content: 1) Buy GREMLINS. 2) Watch GREMLINS 3) Repeat #2 several times Every time I surf the t.v. and I come across GREMLINS, I will put down the remote and watch it til the end. GREMLINS, for its time, was truly groundbreaking. It was E.T., except with really rotten friends and relatives. Well-paced and directed Joe Dante, with unique performances by Zach Galligan and the gorgeous Phoebe Cates, GREMLINS deftly treads in and out of suspense/horror and comedy. (Phoebe Cates' explication of how her father died is still outrageous.) And there are plenty of pitched battles between the good guys and the unruly gremlins to keep the plot moving. Just don't show this movie to young kids around Christmastime. This special edition has a lot of goodies that true GREMLINS fans will enjoy, and the quality is top-notch. Just don't get it wet. I've loved Gremlins since I was a wee girl of only about 5 or 6, and previously my only copy of the film was a tattered VHS, worn out and almost grainy from repeated viewings. I purchased Gremlins on DVD and was astonished at how beautiful the transfer from film to DVD was. The details are crystal clear and the sound is impeccable. Certain small visual details of the movie were totally lost on my old VHS, but stand out gorgeously on this DVD. The movie itself doesn't need further praise from me - it's fun and funny, gory and touching at the same time. My personal favorite scene is when all of the Gremlins are in the movie theater, singing "Hi Ho" right along with the dwarfs in Snow White. The special effects are amazing for the time, the score was perfect, and Gizmo never ceases to be adorable. A must-buy.

title: One Of The 80's Best Movies!
content: This was one of my favorite movies since I saw it as a little kid. I'm pretty sure if my Dad had actually seen what happened in the movie, he would have taken it away from me, but it was safely hidden behind a PG rating, so he didn't mind me watching it (my Mom was much cooler and we would always watch it together). Anyway, I thought it was great then, and I think it's great now. I just re-watched it yesterday, and it's still amazing. What's great is how well director Joe Dante combines all sorts of elements; horror, comedy, romance, etc. Really, I'd call this the most twisted Christmas film ever, even worse than Bad Santa. Yes, they're different, and yes, that movie was one of the sickest films ever (but hilarious), but what makes Gremlins so sick is how it starts of so harmless and cutesy. Bad Santa made no denial that it wasn't for children, but Gremlins tricks you. As it starts, the last thing you expect to be is scared. A peaceful, snowy hometown, kind citizens, a loving dad who brings home a REALLY cute little creature named Gizmo. What's scary about that? Then, after you've safely settled in and are comfortable, Dante pulls the carpet out under you feet and the story turns into one about ugly monsters blowing up in microwaves or being killed in a blender. Dante actually did horror/comedy well. It seems like most movies that claim to be horror/comedies are actually just silly comedies with lots of blood and guts which aren't in the least bit scary. Here, the movie is blood-chillingly scary in scenes, and gut bustingly funny in others. For instance, the scene with the Gremlins wreaking havoc at Dorry's tavern is just plain silly and funny, but the scene with Frances Lee McCain searching the house and finding the creatures in her kitchen is just REALLY scary and creepy. Plus, the acting's great and the special effects are amazing. It makes me sad to think that if any other movie like this was made, they'd use bad CGI that's not at all realistic. People mtalk about how much more advanced movies are today, but I disagree. Which is easier to believe is real: the Gremlins in this movie or Yoda in Star Wars Episode Two? This movie was follwed by a terrific sequel that threw the horror out the window and made no denial to being a flat out comedy, and one of the smartest and most entertaining ever. Don't miss that one, either.

title: An classic films from the 1980's.
content: When a young bank teller (Zach Galligan) receives an unusual mysterious new pet as a gift. When he accidentally disobeys several crucial rules for its care. It's unintentionally spawning an army of blood thirsty, trouble-making monsters.Directed by Joe Dante (The Howling, Innerspace, Small Soldiers) made this deliciously dark, amusing film. This has cuteness, murder, love, mayhem, destruction and more to this beloved popular cult classic. This was one of the biggest hits of 1984. "Gremlins" is a genuinely special film.DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (1.78:1) transfer and an fine digitally remastered-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD has two entertaining commentaries tracks by the cast and filmmakers. DVD also has behind the scenes featurette, photo gallery, original theatrical trailer and more. Steven Spielberg is one of the executive producers of this film. Written by Chris Columbis (The Goonies, Home Alone, Rent). (**** 1/2 out of *****).

title: Gets better with each watch, no water required.
content: Pretty much the prefect combination of comedy and horror (except from that strange, 'don't know whether to laugh or cry' broken-neck Santa story), Joe Dante's seminal, devilishly dark adventure is a downright classic, perfect for every Christmas season, thanks to its wickedly witty writing, gorgeously gooey effects and slightly tongue-in-cheek edge. 'Gremlins (1984)' really is a riotous affair, an almost perfectly paced and plotted genre tightrope walk. It's incredibly entertaining throughout, an invaluably re-watchable experience that, essentially, keeps getting better and better every time you see it. 8/10

title: A comical Christmas movie!
content: Invetor Randy Peltzer (Hoyt Axton) has bought a special and unusual gift for his son Billy (Zach Galligan). It's a furry Chinese creature which is a Mogwai named Gizmo (Voiced by Howie Mandall) whom is cute and cuddly but there are three rules if he wants to keep the thing, number 1 is Don't get it wet, number 2 is keep it away from the light especially sunlight cause sunlight would kill it and the most important rule is never feed it after midnight. Billy does what he can but accidentally gets Gizmo wet which makes it multiply other Mogwais and also accidentally fed the other Mogwaii except Gizmo after midnight. It somehow transforms the cuddly creatures into vicious and intelligent reptilian ghouls that start attacking the town of Kingston Falls.An original and brilliant horror fantasy from Joe Dante and producer Steven Spielberg is one of the greatest movies of the 80's! the film became one of the biggest box-office hits of 1984 and of all time thanks to the magic of it's original screenplay by Chris Columbus, great acting and excellent creature effects. It also incorporates satire and dark humor with gruesomeness, the film co-stars Dick Miller, Corey Feldman, and Phoebe Cates with appearance by Chuck Jones. Along with "Indiana Jones and The Temple of Doom" the following year, it drew big time controversy among parents who thought the film was too violent for kids and the MPAA created PG-13 that year. Chris Walas's special effects are just outstanding with the lovable fur-balls and the not-so-lovable monsters that made them memorable.The film has been imitated throughout the years until the early 90's with films like "Ghoulies", "Munchies", "Evil Toons", "Beasties", "Troll", "Elves", "Spookies" and the worst one of them all "Hobgoblins". Although "Critters 1 & 2" were exceptions cause those were fun movies in their own right. This is a classic film for the holidays even Halloween, i also recommended the brilliant yet underrated sequel.

title: One of my favourite 1980s films of all time
content: I've watched this 1984 American comedy horror film loads of times. It's kinda creepy and violent but it is still very good and funny as well.It might be perfect for Halloween despite being set in Christmas time.Its original release date is 8th June 1984 while the film is being set in Christmastime. That is far too early to release any Christmas films at cinemas in the month of June as we know. Who wants to watch Christmas films during the summer? It should have been released at cinemas in December same year. But it doesn't matter anyway.It never gets old and it will always be a timeless classic. It's probably one of the best 1980s films of all time. It is also one of my favourite 1980s films of all time.

title: Gremlins rule!
content: I didn't see this movie till Summer 2005.But I gotta say that i enjoyed the movie a lot.Gremlins is about Gizmo a furry Monwaki who is bought by a traveling salesman who wanted to find the perfect Christmas present for his son, Billy.In order to take care of this creature, you have to follow 3 rules. 1. Let it near bright light, Sunlight can kill it. 2. Don't let it get near any source of water 3. NEVER feed it after midnightIf you do feed these types of creatures after midnight. You'll be seeing some nasty results.Gremlins are vicious and mischievous creatures. They like to dismantle machinery and have the pleasure of killing people.It's up to Billy and his new little friend Gizmo to eliminate the Gremlins before they turn the whole town upside down.If I saw this movie years before I'd be scared to death if I saw it for the first time as a kid.It's rated PG. Violent and thrilling for a PG movie. I recommend it to Ages 10 and up. Please know this movie may frighten little kids. I know I'd be if I did saw it as a kid.But Gremlins is highly recommended to those who like to see little creatures attacking.

title: A Christmas Classic To Be Enjoyed Anytime
content: Gizmo is my spirit animal.Gremlins is truly an epic achievement on all levels. The script, the effects, that score is an ear worm that will never leave your brain, it's just that good!This is one of my most beloved and cherished movies from the 80's. It's both Christmas-y and sentimental, but also dark and twisted.And fun.And funny.Joe Dante, please make more like this!

title: Who are we supposed to root for?
content: The late 70s and 80s have blessed us with bogeymen beyond count: Pinhead, Freddy, Jason, Mike Myers, Candyman... all speaking to a collective subconscious desire to watch a hapless protagonist - more often than not squeaky-clean, young, white and female - bite the dust.Gremlins is a cinematic anomaly of their weirdest variety. Part slasher film, part parody, part Christmas movie, it turns all three of these sub-genres on their heads and manages to give us the very best they can deliver. It follows Billy Peltzer and his brand new pet Mogwai, Gizmo. Gizmo is an instantly lovable creature, semi-legally imported from China, but he comes with his very strict set of rules: do not expose him to sunlight, do not get him wet, and never, ever feed him after midnight. It doesn't take a genius to imagine where things go from here, but it did take geniuses of a kind to created what we end up witnessing.The Gremlins themselves are wonderfully inventive, nasty little bastards, and watching them pillage their way through mid-80s suburban America is an unmitigated joy. Whether it's wreaking havoc at a local movie theater or hot-wiring traffic lights, their mischievousness makes them lovable and relatable in a sick, twisted way. As such, bar the core relationship between Gizmo and Billy, the human characters are efficiently but economically set up, enough so that we care when evil strikes, but never at the expense of the film's warped idea of fun.It's a cult movie, but one of the highest order, made very skillfully by people who were clearly in love with every iota of the concept. Rarely has a film been so much fun.

I guess you could rank this one as a "holiday classic." A kid gets a Mowgwi (against the original owner's advice) from his father, a klutzy inventor, as a Christmas gift. All hell breaks loose when he inadvertently breaks the "rules," especially the one not to feed the pets after midnight. One of the offsprings jumps in the pool, reproduces like mad, and the next thing you know, the peaceful little town isn't so peaceful anymore. I loved the mischief played by the creatures and the attempts to get everything back to normal. My favorites:the scenes with the mean old lady and the line "You hate Washington's Birthday and no one thinks anything of it but if you hate Christmas they think you're a leper." This ranks as one of my all-time favorite movies-I loved it! You will too.*** out of ****

title: Just a wonderful little number
content: This lil baddie right here I SWEAR is SUCH a fun movie. The animatronics (or however you spell it) are succulentttttttttIt's so whimsical and silly and sweet but dark and sharp at the same time it's just a BLAST. I loved this for its cuteness as much I loved it for its bloodier moments.It was also the first "horror" type movie I ever saw!!!!Also the "after midnight" loophole is pretty funny.Ugh so yeah the movie is sick af and a classic.I wish I could watch it for the first time over and over again!!!

title: Devilishly dark and fiendishly funny, Gremlins with its unique mixture of horror and comedy makes for an entertaining watch.
content: Set in the town of Kingston Falls, a young man named Billy Peltzer (Zach Galligan) works as a bank teller supporting his parents Lynn (Frances Lee McCain) and Rand (Hoyt Axton) during a Christmas season where many are feeling financial pressure from the town's cruel landlord Ruby Deagle (Polly Holliday). When Rand comes home from trying to sell his inventions yet again, he gives Billy a gift of a creature he acquired in Chinatown called a mogwai whom he named Gizmo (Howie Mandel). Rand tells Billy of three rules in owning the Mogwai 1) he hates bright lights especially sunlight which will kill him 2) don't let him near water and 3) don't feed him after midnight. However when Billy inadvertently allows lapses of the second and third rules a horde of deformed mogwai known as "gremlins" are unleashed upon the town wreaking havoc.Gremlins began as a spec script by writer Chris Columbus inspired by the noises rodents would make in a loft he once lived in. Columbus had written the script with no intention of it actually being filmed and only to showcase his writing skills until Steven Spielberg took an interest in the script having come upon it. Spielberg enlisted Joe Dante due to the director's experience in horror-comedy with Spielberg having praised Dante's Piranha as the best of the wave of Jaws knock-offs and also for his work on The Howling. The script went through a few drafts toning down some darker aspects of the film though some aspects such as Kate's Santa Claus story made it in despite Spielberg not liking the scene. Upon release the film opened at number two behind Ghostbusters and both films were runaway successes with Gremlins becoming the fourth highest grossing film of 1984 making $219 million against an $11 million budget. Gremlins has maintained a presence in the pop culture zeitgeist thanks to its unique mixture of over the top dark humor mixed with horror elements, and the movie spawned large numbers of imitators too numerous to mention. Despite repeated attempts to recapture Gremlins success, Gremlins remains the definitive film about diminutive hellraising maniacs.As typical of Spielberg produced films of the era, Gremlins has the same focus on "small town America" that was used to solid effect in noted Spielberg genre fare such as E. T. The Extraterrestrial and Close Encounters of the Third Kind but taking a more fantastical approach with the premise in comparison to the sci-fi approach. Despite working with a larger budget than Piranha and The Howling, Joe Dante very much approaches the material in the same vein as a fifties monster movie with references in movie to sic-fi classics such as Invasion of the Body Snatchers while also indulging in the various b-movie drive-in tropes popularized in fifties films such as The Blob complete with quirky eccentric small town's people, disbelieving sheriffs, and eccentric old timers who no one believes until it's too late. The movie does a good job of giving us fully fleshed out characters who we care about and derives humor from the various eccentricities and personalities, and the buildup to the chaos brought about by the swarm of gremlins overrunning the town is filled with memorable character moments as well as visual moments that are still remembered and quoted today.Gremlins ranks along with Ghostbusters in establishing that unique mixture of horror and comedy that came about in the 80s and has influenced the approaches of several others that followed in its wake. Both disturbing and darkly amusing, Gremlins remains a unique pop cultural milestone that many have attempted to copy with varying degrees of success.

title: It "is" a Christmas movie!
content: Like Die Hard, the debate with gremlins will always rage on, is it a Xmas movie?Well I think yes. Plus not only that, it's actually one one my favourites. The opening credits to the Darlene Love song is still one of my favourite openings of all time.I believe this and the howling are Joe Dante's biggest achievements, it's a shame he's not making films anymore. Only about an hour and a half long, it's a perfect movie to watch at Xmas. The pacing is perfect, the film never gets boring, whether it's introducing the characters, setting the scene or starting the chaos.The effects are surprisingly decent considering it was made in 1984 (38 years ago when writing).I've been watching this every Xmas with my little boy since he was about 6 and my little girl now she's 8. It's daft enough not to be scary for kids, but enough threat to be invested in the safety of the characters.A fantastically well made film.

title: Still good
content: Watching this in 2021. Classic and still one of my favorite movies of all time.

title: Mischieviously clever!
content: This is what I can say is clever, quirky, and very entertaining. "Gremlins" is by chance a clever and witty movie by Steven Spielberg. This fantasy/horror/comedy is well made and very fun to watch. Having a pet is always a hassle, yet it can be fun. When you have a Mogwai, you're will to pay a high price. A inventor wannabe named Randall Peltzer(Hoyt Axton) is buying a gift for his son Billy(Zach Galligan), the owner's grandson(John Louie) gives Ran the three important rules:1) Never give it water, 2) Keep it out of bright light, 3) Never feed him after midnight. Did Billy abide by the rules? NO! Those cute furry Mogwois become these hideous green gremlins, and they spread terror all over the small town. But somehow, these guys were beneficial in one way, they scared the living daylights out of poor Mrs. Deagle(Polly Holliday, "Alice", "Flo", "Mrs. Doubtfire") she was not well-liked in town. He heart was bad, the gremlins made it go away. HAHAHA! I liked the bar scene where all of them were having fun, and I liked the gremlin with the leg-warmers did all the dancing to Michael Sembello's song. They have one soft spot in the movie, Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs". The movie was entertaining and very funny in the process, my brother's first girlfriend was frightened by this movie, my brother? E.T. You must have guts, watch it. 5 stars!

title: The definitive Christmas horror film
content: I don't know possible it is to watch Gremlins and not immediately get on board. From its very beginning, it's a movie that pulls you in and really never lets go. It envelopes you with a warm, comforting Christmas vibe but underneath the surface, there's a tinge of the ever present darkness, frustration, and sadness associated with the holiday too.Gremlins strikes an essentially perfect tone; it's funny, it's manic, it's heart warming and cute. It's just dark enough that you take what happens seriously, but not too dark that it'd put off people during the season.It also has some genuinely fun and interesting characters; little details like Billy's Dad being a crackpot inventor or Phoebe Cates' character having a truly devastating reason she hates Christmas give the film life and energy. It's not a bunch of boring, paper thin people we meet; even though they aren't the focus, you don't HATE whenever normal people are on screen.But let's be real. The Gremlins are the star of the show here.I can go on about the creature effects and animatronics here; the 1980s were a golden age of puppetry and practical effects, and Gremlins stands tall as some of the most impressive and enduring I've ever seen. It's remarkable how it holds up and also kind of surprising no one's ruined it with a totally CG remake yet (although, I'm sure that's coming - eventually).They have so much personality and an infectious mischievous energy; almost like that guy you know who's tons of fun to party with, but also doesn't know when the party ends. They're also legitimately scary at times and a real threat; the movie has stakes and it's now hard to see why their Chinese name, "mogwai", directly translates to "devil" or "demon."They almost personify the negative elements of Christmas, contrasted with the sweet innocence of Gismo. The rapacious consumption and entitlement we can't pretend doesn't exist with the holiday. (There's also a not-so-subtle message about the West not understanding and respecting cultural norms and guardrails of the East that I found pretty interesting for what is otherwise a pretty straightforward creature feature)But yeah, at the end of the day, if you haven't seen this movie yet...what are you waiting for. It's truly awesome in every way.

title: Joe Dante's masterpiece
content: "Gremlins" is a wildly entertaining movie. It is filled with humor and is very exciting at times. There are two or three scenes in this movie that are truly amazing pieces of filmmaking. Director joe Dante and company crafted together an excellent movie. The cast is very good with one strong performance after another. The standouts in the cast are Francis Lee McCain, Howie Mandel (voice) and a never better Dick Miller. "Gremlins" is one of the best movies to come out of the 1980's. I first saw this movie in the theater. I've seen it a bunch of times since. It never fails to hit the spot. Honorable mention: the music.

title: A bundle of joy perfect to unwrap around the holidays
content: The film isn't an ordinary Christmas movie, as it cleverly mixes horror and comedy into the holiday season. After a recent rewatch, I can gladly say it is a rollercoaster of a time, which can surprisingly provide some hard hitting moments.Each Gremlin possesses their own unique personality, with the little creatures arguably being the minions of their time. It's so entertaining watching them tumble into self-induced sticky situations, and how (if) they manage to get themselves out of it. Through scenes like these, Dante does very well to make them seem like intelligent creatures who were (literally) born yesterday.The music in the film adds a goofy touch to the film, preparing the audience for the silly scenarios which will come later. I particularly enjoyed Mrs Deagle's theme song - however, the instruments used made me take the character less seriously (which may've been the artists intention).On the topic of Mrs Deagle, each smaller character is equally as interesting as the main. This is due to how well written their few lines are. This also includes Mr Futterman, whose introduction to the idea of Gremlins adds irony to the upcoming events.I was left in awe of the cinematography in the film, especially the many long ones which capture the whole atmosphere of the town.Overall, Gremlins is an incredible film which is perfect to watch around the holidays (or not, if you don't think it's a Christmas film) and I'd 100% recommend it if anyone who hasn't seen it is looking for a fun, classic film to watch.

title: "The worst thing that ever happened to me was on Christmas."
content: Infamous at the time of its release as being marketed as a PG family film produced by Steven Spielberg, it's really a covert monster movie from the director of THE HOWLING and PIRANHA. This film, along with INDIANA JONES AND THE TEMPLE OF DOOM, also rated PG, which included someone's still beating heart being torn out of their chest, promoted the MPAA to create the new PG-13 rating. GREMLINS was written by Chris Columbus, whose next script would be the true family classic THE GOONIES, here tells the story of Zach Galligan getting a pet Gremlin for an early Christmas present (Howie Mandel voices Gizmo's coos, grunts, and squeals) from his dad, Hoyt Axton, but the new pet comes with a few rules:Do not expose to bright lights.Do not let them get wet.No feeding after midnight.Not to spoil anything, but you can probably guess what happens. When what you guess does happen, all sort of mayhem breaks loose with "bad" gremlins running amok. What ensures is stabbings, decapitations, deaths by blender, and my favorite, death by being blown up in the microwave. The other most non-child friendly scene is one where Phoebe Cates tells her boyfriend Galligan a story of how "The worst thing that ever happened to me was on Christmas" which involves a missing father, rotting corpses stuck in a chimney, and learning that Santa isn't real. How's that for family fun humor? The studio wanted that part removed because they felt it was too ambiguous as to whether it was supposed to be funny or sad. Director Joe Dante refused to take the scene out, saying it represented this movie as a whole, which had a combination of horrific and comedic elements. Executive producer Steven Spielberg did not like the scene either, but despite his creative control, he viewed this movie as Dante's project and allowed him to leave it in. Dante's cheeky snark permeates this film, as well as his usual film-buff inside jokes (Robbie the Robot from FORBIDDEN PLANET and the time machine from THE TIME MACHINE are in the background in one scene, the smiley face sticker from THE HOWLING can be seen in another, and casting Hollywood Golden Age character actors Keye Luke, Harry Carey Jr., Edward Andrews, Edward Arnold, Dante stock company actor Dick Miller, and quite a few more. There's even a cameo by Looney Tunes director Chuck Jones). Overall, Gremlins is terrific nasty fun, but don't go into it expecting a family-friendly experience. This one is more of a gateway horror film for kids to help get them into the harder stuff. FUN FACT! The town square set for Kingston Falls is very clearly the same town square used for clock tower town scenes in BACK TO THE FUTURE, both filmed on the Universal Studios backlot.

title: The quintessential Christmas horror movie
content: Like, I imagine, many who grew up with it, I both loved and was terrified by Gremlins as a kid. As an adult, it is still a ton of fun. It plays out like a classic monster movie, if slightly more kid friendly. The titular creatures didn't appear in full until fifty minutes in, a classic trope of the genre. Everything before that is spent introducing the characters and setting, establishing the rules involving the creatures, and building up to their inevitable reveal. The buildup is perfectly paced and does a solid job of building suspense. But of course, as you'd expect, once the Gremlins do appear, that's when the real fun begins. The antics they get up to, the chaos they wreck and the different ways they are dispatched are both hilarious and terrifying. The only exceptions to this are the bar scene and when they sing along to Snow White, which are just hilarious, and Kate's backstory and Stripe's death, which are just terrifying. Helping matters is the top notch puppetry done on both Gizmo and the Gremlins, Joe Dante's direction, and Jerry Goldsmith's score, which off-sets classic Christmas tunes with a creepy theme for the Gremlins. We do have to deal with the annoying scene where the hero goes to the police, like they'd ever believe his story, but thankfully it doesn't last long.As far as protagonists go, Billy and Kate are a little bland, but they're likeable enough and have decent chemistry. Billy has even better chemistry with Gizmo, who comes out as the real star of the film. He's adorable, charming, and very smart, and his design and puppetry are some of the best in the film. I love this character so much I once named my cat after him. Billy's parents are great too; his dad's inventions are funny, as are the ways he pitches them, and the mom shows how tough she is by taking out several Gremlins. The rest of the cast is solid too. The only characters I didn't like are the ones played by Judge Reinhold and Polly Holiday, and I'm not supposed to like them.Overall, Gremlins is a true classic, for me and for many who grew up with it. It can be really intense, so I wouldn't recommend it for really little kids. But, for older kids, they're sure to have a fun time. Same with the sequel, which is really underrated.

title: These Little Devils Keep Us Entertained
content: Gremlins just want to have fun, and it's fun watching them do so. These creepy little monsters are mischievous and hilarious. title: Very good
content: This Christmas, I decided to rewatch Gremlins since I barely remembered anything from the first time I saw it as a kid. Now, I completely understand why it's so beloved. Directed by Joe Dante, the film strikes a perfect balance between horror and comedy, making it a unique and memorable experience that's accessible to any audience without ever compromising its tone.While there are elements of horror, they never cross the line. There are no graphic or overly disturbing scenes, and it's not particularly scary. Yes, there are deaths, but most are hilarious and add to the chaotic and fun nature of the Gremlins. It's rare to find a film that blends light horror and laughs so effectively.The creatures, of course, are the stars of the show. The Gremlins have such distinct personalities-they're charismatic and captivating, even as they wreak havoc. Then there's Gizmo, the adorable little Mogwai. It's impossible not to fall in love with him; he's one of the cutest creatures in cinema and truly the heart of the movie.The human characters also deserve praise. There's great chemistry between the actors, which makes the relationships feel authentic amidst all the chaos. The cast manages to balance seriousness and humor naturally, which is crucial for the film's dynamic.For me, Gremlins is perfect for the holiday season. It's the kind of film that blends festive spirit with plenty of adventure and fun. Without a doubt, it has become one of my favorite movies from the 1980s. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for something different yet equally magical to enjoy at this time of year.

title: A Chaotic Christmas Classic!
content: 'Gremlins' is such a high quality classic! I cannot praise it enough and I can see why I loved it so much as a youngster.The puppetry and special effects on the Gizmo and the other Mogwai was beyond exceptional! You can see so much character in their facial expressions and movements. Plus, Gizmo is just so remarkably cute. I do not know how anyone can resist his adorable design.Furthermore, the music is so memorable. The main theme for Gizmo completely captures his calm and adorable nature. While, the manic gremlins rag theme emphasises the absolute chaos on screen.I loved revisiting this film as an adult and being able to understand the symbolism on display. The themes of otherness and foreign culture are so well integrated. It does have to use certain stereotypes to achieve this thematic effect, but I do not believe it is in bad spirit. This is a must-see Christmas watch!

title: The Origins Of PG-13!!!
content: Everything about this film rules.It blends the lighthearted magic of Spielberg, with the iconic horror touch of Joe Dante, to create what is arguably the best Christmas themed horror film ever made.Certainly the most iconic, anyways.With the Gremlins being among the most lovably mischievous villains ever created.If only to market the film around a merchandising campaign.And it's also the first ever PG-13 rated movie.As Spielberg lobbied the MPAA (Motion Picture Association of America), to create a new classification, which would allow teenagers to view the film in cinemas (when it would have otherwise been given an R rating, that would have prevented them from seeing it.Thankfully, this film was made in the 80's, with entirely practical effects, from puppeteering, to stop motion...whereas, if it were made today...the whole thing would no doubt, be reliant upon overworked and exploited CGI animators...which would inevitably have rendered it a far inferior production.Which makes you wonder how 2023's Gremlins 3 is going to turn out...It tells the coming of age story of a boy named Jack, who is gifted a living creature- called a Mogwai- by his failed inventor father, for Christmas.The gift comes with 3 rules: keep it away from bright light (sunlight will kill it); don't get it wet (as water will cause it to multiply); and don't feed it after midnight (less it metamorphose into it's demonic Gremlin form).And, of course, our anti-hero protagonist breaks all 3- if only accidentally- to set off Kingston Falls' own isolated apocalypse.When it comes to the creatures, it's not only their lifelike features that are so alluring, but also their intelligence.Which really allows you to empathize with- and even love- these mischievous little devils.Especially Gizmo, who is not only cute and cuddly, but has the loveable features we became endeared with (as kids) through ET.Though, even in their Gremlin form, their rebellious nature resonated with us as youths growing up and getting into trouble before the digital age had fully come to fruition, and become omnipresent.Plus, with the horror elements being darkly comical in nature, it really is the perfect film to harken in the era of PG-13.Not being scary enough to warrant an R rating, while being to untame to be classified as PG (not to mention, it contains a few swears).It snuggles itself right into that middle ground between the two, while speaking to the rebellious nature of us kids growing up as misspent youths, where it fits right in.The only real surprising thing here, is that it never spawned more sequels!Having ended off as a canonical duology...only spawning an animated tv series almost 40 years later (in 2022), and a third film in the trilogy (slated for 2023).Because there are so many gremlins, it really allowed them to run the gamut of representation...and thus connect with practically everyone, no matter what societal niche you fit into.Perhaps, it is because their origins are slightly xenophobic...though, even then...they are fighting back, and getting their comeuppance.Either way...you just can't help but love this film...because it really is one of those films that "they just don't make anymore".So let's all hope that Gremlins 3 can live up to the iconic legacy that this film (and it's sequel) have established.Because if they stray too far into CGI territory...it really will be a travesty worth rebelling against.An absolute classic, that just gets better with age.8.5 out of 10.

title: Silly but infectious fun
content: I will admit some of it is very silly, but all the same it is infectious fun from start to finish. Directed by Joe Dante, produced by Steven Spielburg and written by Chris Columbus, Gremlins has quickly established itself in my opinion as a comedy horror classic. The direction is rock solid throughout, and is super efficient. The script is funny and inventive, and the story growing from a very simple idea is engaging and delightful. Plus all the characters are credible. And I have to say Jerry Goldsmith's music is a treat, that man knows how to compose a good music score I can tell you. Haunting, shocking and exciting are three ways to describe the score here. The gremlins are the scene stealers here, at first they are very cute then all of a sudden when they start causing carnage they are quite the opposite. But the acting from the human actors is just as good. Zach Galligan is bland at first, but as the film gets going and you know more of his character you warm to him. Hoyt Axton is indeed a hoot as the inept inventor, and Keye Luke is great as the Grandfather(Mr Wing). Also watch out for a young Corey Feldman as Pete Fountaine. Plus the Christmas speech makes it essential Christmas viewing. All in all, silly it is, but it is clever and consistently engaging. Not only that, it succeeds at both comedy and horror, and that isn't easy to do.

title: An iconic 80's festive horror comedy
content: While looking for an ideal Christmas present for his teenage son in Chinatown Billy, Randall Peltetzer comes across a furry Creature called a Mogwai which he thinks will make the ideal pet. There are however strict rules that come with it. Don't expose it to bright light as it will kill him, don't expose it to water and never feed it after midnight. When two of the three rules are contravened, Billy's hometown of Kingston Falls is plunged into chaos as it is overrun by hordes of nasty, malicious little monsters. Now It's up to Billy to put a stop to the Gremlin menace.The brainchild of Chris Columbus (with Steven Spielberg acting as Executive Producer), the inspiration behind this 1984 Horror comedy which celebrates It's 40 year anniversary came from the 1920's when mechanical failures in RAF aircraft were jokingly blamed on the small monsters. The term "gremlins" became a part of pop culture, with Roald Dahl himself publishing a children's book called The Gremlins in 1943. Director Joe Dante read the book, stating that it was of some influence on the movie 1984, was most definitely a good year for Hollywood blockbusters with Ghostbusters and Indiana Jones & the Temple of Doom hitting theatre's across the globe. And Gremlins was one of them. The character of Gizmo, the lovable, adorable furry little creature becoming a merchandisers dream, with toys of the little guy selling like hot cakes. And who else can't forget the computer game that followed? It was a festive, Christmas movie which was something of a contrast to your typical fare of the same ilk.Its iconography is undeniable. Fairly dark with some black humour thrown into the mix, and some cutesy moments from the endearing fur ball. The movie' went through several drafts before the final one that made it to the screen was finalized. The first one being considerably even darker than what we got. Scene's included Billy's dog being eaten, his mother being killed by the savage little monstrosities and them descending on a McDonald's restaurant where they eat all the customers. This proved darker than what the filmmakers wanted and therefore it was toned down.The end result is still fairly grim, involving some deliciously macabre moments. With some lighter ones thrown in to to the mix to offer some respite from the nastiness that abounds. One memorable scenario features Billy's mother having to fend off several of the pesky beasts, and involving some novel methods in which she chooses to dispatch them. Which include the use of a blender and a microwave.Dante wisely has his cast playing it straight without playfully winking to the audience. Zach Galligan, in what would be the highlight of a career, having eventually dwindled into obscurity makes for a personable, mild mannered hero. Perpetually perturbed by the mayhem that he has found himself and the local townspeople have been thrown into. Hoyt Axton is wonderfully eccentric and affable as his Dad, Randall. And who can forget Polly Holliday as the mean-spirited, battleaxe from hell Mrs. Deagle. Who gets more than a well deserved case of gold old fashioned comeuppance. Waiting stage right is Joe Dante regular Dick Miller on hand as Billy's neighbour Mr. Futterman. Indeliable still is Phoebe Cates's haunting monologue on how she learned that there was no Santa Claus, which more than leaves by it's mark. Also look out for appearances from Jonathan Banks of Breaking Bad fame, Judge Reinhold and Corey Feldman.The movie delights in some little nods to 80's pop culture, with references to Flashdance, replete with break dancing Gremlins. It also subverts the age old tropes of the traditional Christmas cinematic tradition. It would prove so influential that it would spawn a series of cheap knock offs which include Critters, Ghoulies, Troll and Munchies. None of which could hold a candle to it. Topped off by Jerry Goldsmith's sublime score which captures the right note of manic absurdity. Gremlins is a festive treat with some added bite.

title: Gremlins
